content.webTitle: Allardyce concerned about Sunderland future despite Bilic support

fields.headline: Allardyce concerned about Sunderland future despite Bilic support
fields.bodyText: Slaven Bilic was talking in a cramped anteroom to the West Ham media centre when Sam Allardyce, perhaps touring the Upton Park corridors for one last time, emerged from a side door. “See you next season, hopefully,” the Sunderland manager said to his counterpart as they clasped hands. “You will, you will,” came the response. With that, Allardyce was gone. It had been a trying afternoon, one that offered him none of the certainty evinced by Bilic about Sunderland’s survival prospects. Allardyce’s return to east London had been greeted with apathy by his former public and most of the fare that ensued inspired a similar feeling. Yet his side squandered enough chances to take a late point and the overriding sense afterwards was one of disquiet. “The massive disappointment is we know we should have got a result, and with the position we’re in it was imperative we came away with at least a point,” Allardyce said. “We’ve made life extremely hard for ourselves by not getting one. You have to be encouraged by the performance, but for them not to convert any of their chances is a real concern to me. Losing that today is difficult to take, very difficult.” His body language was downbeat and that seemed to be overdoing things slightly. Sunderland’s cause is far from lost and, on current form, a home fixture against Crystal Palace on Tuesday appears an ideal pick-me-up. Jermain Defoe and Jack Rodwell, the latter twice, should certainly have buried presentable opportunities in the second half but it was tempting to wonder whether Allardyce, with his clear sense of pride at the foundations he established in four years at Upton Park, had invested more in this fixture than he was prepared to let on. “I think the lads know that without me saying it,” he said when asked whether the desire to win on his old turf had featured in his team talk, and it evidently hurt that the occasion had fallen flat. West Ham’s rise under Bilic underlines the parties’ contrasting directions of travel. Michail Antonio’s well-taken first-half winner, aided by generous defending from Patrick van Aanholt, keeps them firmly in the contest for European places, even if this was not their most convincing display. They have tended to find life tougher against the lesser sides than those near the top but, for Bilic, any victory is a sign that his team are handling increased expectations. “The pressure is there,” he said. “We are a little bit the victims of our own success. Some of the press might have thought, ‘Sunderland, it should be easy’, but no way. They beat Manchester United and drew at Anfield. But it comes because of our points and performances so far.” That combination means continental football at the Olympic Stadium – and not of the type that saw FC Lusitans, Birkirkara and Astra Giurgiu usher in Upton Park’s final season – cannot be discounted and Bilic was content to allow such thoughts to run. “If I say ‘we don’t have a chance’, then a lot of people will think I don’t believe in my team,” he said. “If I say ‘yeah, we’ve got a chance’, then I’ve become big-headed or whatever. I’ll leave you to make a calculation.” West Ham’s progress has already been such that no mathematics could really come up with an answer unsatisfactory to Bilic; how things add up for Allardyce between now and May is far less clear. Man of the match Michail Antonio (West Ham United)
